title: Why celebrities go to extreme lengths to stay in the spotlight
text:
Social media has changed the game when it comes to celebrity.

Fame was once the preserve of actors, sports stars and artists who worked on their trade for years using carefully honed skills and talents. But now it's so much easier to find your space in the spotlight.

Wannabe stars are making a name for themselves by posing on Instagram, performing stunts on YouTube, lip-syncing on TikTok, and hooking up on reality TV shows.

Frankie Grande (left) and Brittany Furlan (right) are part of a new generation of social media personalities who have risen to prominence quickly and have found the fame intoxicating

But this easy fame has come at a price. This week's E! True Hollywood Story will investigate how the 'high' that comes from fame can have worrying consequences.

In a trailer for the upcoming episode, addiction specialist Dr Drew Pinsky says: 'Fame can be as addictive as any drug.'

The episode will look at how some of Hollywood's biggest stars, such as Justin Bieber, Lindsay Lohan and Britney Spears, have crumbled under the pressures of fame.

But it will also investigate how fame is having powerful side effects on the new wave of social media personalities who are ill-equipped to deal with sudden stardom.

These instant celebrities face an uphill battle to stay in the spotlight since their shelf life tends to be more limited than Hollywood stars. But their desire to stay famous is no less intense.

Dr Pinsky and other experts point out how the instant and intense gratifying effect of fame can be addictive, driving stars to go to extreme measures in their quest for approval and adoration.

Britney Spears (left) and Lindsay Lohan (right) have both suffered very public meltdowns after finding fame at a young age and struggling to withstand the pressures of celebrity

Brittany Furlan became famous almost overnight thanks to her six-second clips on Vine, which earned her ten million followers. But when her popularity began to dwindle, Brittany's attempts to stay in the spotlight led her down a dark path.

She was accused of being racist in some of her clips, faced vicious criticism for her high-profile relationship, and posted highly sexual photos on Instagram which she now admits went too far.

YouTuber Logan Paul also knows what it's like when the tide turns. He famously faced an overwhelming backlash after posting a picture of himself with a dead body in Japan's 'suicide forest' Aokigahara.

Frankie Grande, brother of superstar songstress Ariana Grande, is another social media star who struggled with an obsessive desire for fame.

For Frankie this led to drugs and alcohol as he struggled to deal with online criticism and bullying, which he said nearly destroyed his life.

E! True Hollywood Story will investigate these cases and more when Is Fame an Addiction? airs on Sunday November 3.
